0.user_question: Jerry was helping the cafeteria workers pick up lunch trays, but he could only carry 8 trays at a time. If he had to pick up 9 trays from one table and 7 trays from another, how many trips will he make?

ost_step.2: Determine the number of trips needed for picking up the trays from the first table. There are 9 trays on this table, so Jerry needs one more trip than what he can carry in one go. That makes it 9 trays / 8 trays/trip + 1 = 1 full load + 1 extra load = 2 trips.
ost_step.3: Determine the number of trips needed for picking up the trays from the second table. There are 7 trays on this table, so Jerry can pick them all up in one trip since he can carry 8 trays or more.

direct_answer.text: Jerry can pick up 8 trays at a time, so he would need 9 trays / 8 trays/load + 1 trip for the first table. This amounts to 2 trips. For the second table, which contains 7 trays, Jerry can pick them all up in 1 trip since he can carry more than that amount. Therefore, the total number of trips Jerry makes is 2. The answer is: 2.

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. Jerry can carry 8 trays at a time. To take all 9 trays from the first table, he will need to make one trip since 9 <= 8. Since he cannot carry both sets of trays at once, Jerry needs to make a minimum of 3 trips. 1 trip to pick up trays from table 1 and 2 trips to pick up trays from table 2 (one for the first 7 trays and another for the remaining 1 tray). The answer is: 3.
